title: Pole mass
text:
In <a href="quantum%20field%20theory">quantum field theory</a>, the pole mass of an elementary particle corresponds to the concept of <a href="rest%20mass">rest mass</a> in the <a href="special%20theory%20of%20relativity">special theory of relativity</a>.
Running mass.
In quantum field theory, quantities like <a href="coupling%20constant">coupling constant</a> and <a href="mass">mass</a> "run" with the <a href="energy%20scale">energy scale</a> of <a href="high%20energy%20physics">high energy physics</a>. The running mass of a fermion or massive boson depends on the energy scale at which the observation occurs, in a way described by a <a href="Exact%20renormalization%20group%20equation">renormalization group equation</a> (RGE) and calculated by a renormalization scheme such as the <a href="on-shell%20scheme">on-shell scheme</a> or the <a href="minimal%20subtraction%20scheme">minimal subtraction scheme</a>. The running mass refers to a <a href="Lagrangian%20%28field%20theory%29">Lagrangian</a> parameter whose value changes with the energy scale at which the renormalization scheme is applied. A calculation, typically done by a computerized algorithm intractable by paper calculations, relates the running mass to the pole mass. The algorithm typically relies on a perturbative calculation of the <a href="self%20energy">self energy</a>.
Propagator pole.
A loop in a <a href="Feynman%20diagram">Feynman diagram</a> requires an integral over a continuum of possible energies and momenta. In general, the integrals of products of <a href="Propagator%23Propagators%20in%20Feynman%20diagrams">Feynman propagator</a>s diverge at propagator poles, and the divergences must be removed by renormalization. The process of renormalization might be thought of as a theory of cancellations of virtual particle paths, thus revealing the "bare" or renormalized physics, such as the pole mass.
